    Hy gpt, I want you to behave as an expert in web devloppement. I'm a student in mecanical engineering, I want to create a personal website as a cv/resume. Can you help me ?
    ChatGPT

    Absolutely, I can help guide you through creating a personal website as a CV/resume. Here's a step-by-step approach:

    1. Define the Purpose and Content

      • List the information you want to include: education, work experience, skills, projects, contact information, and any relevant achievements.

    2. Choose a Development Approach

      • Template-based platforms: Easy to use, no coding needed (e.g., Wix, Squarespace, Weebly).
      • Content Management Systems (CMS): More flexible, some coding might be required (e.g., WordPress).
      • From Scratch: Using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Ideal if you have some web development skills or want to learn.

    3. Design

      • Layout: Choose a clean, professional layout. Consider a single-page design for simplicity.
      • Color Scheme and Fonts: Select a color scheme and fonts that are easy to read and professional.
      • Responsive Design: Ensure your website looks good on all devices (desktop, tablet, mobile).

    4. Develop the Website

      • If using a template or CMS, follow their guidelines to build your site.
      • If coding from scratch:
        • HTML: Structure your content.
        • CSS: Style your content (colors, fonts, layout).
        • JavaScript: Add interactivity, if needed.

    5. Optimize and Test

      • Check for mobile responsiveness.
      • Test in different browsers.
      • Optimize loading times (compress images, minify CSS/JS).

    6. SEO and Accessibility

      • Basic SEO: Use relevant keywords, add meta tags for description and title.
      • Accessibility: Ensure your site is accessible to users with disabilities (appropriate color contrasts, alt text for images).

    7. Domain and Hosting

      • Purchase a domain name (preferably yourname.com).
      • Choose a hosting provider (many offer easy integration with WordPress and other CMS).

    8. Launch and Maintain

      • Once everything is set, launch your website.
      • Regularly update your CV/resume and maintain the site.

    9. Extra Features (Optional)

      • Blog: Share your thoughts on mechanical engineering or other interests.
      • Portfolio: Showcase any projects or work you've done.
      • Contact Form: Allow visitors to easily get in touch with you.

    Remember, the key to a successful personal website is simplicity, professionalism, and keeping it up-to-date.

    I want you to create a very basic cv template in HTML for beggining
    ChatGPT

    Certainly! I'll create a simple HTML template for a CV/resume. This template will be basic and designed for beginners, focusing on simplicity and readability. You can later customize it with CSS and JavaScript as per your requirements.

    Here's a basic structure:

    html
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Your Name - Resume</title>
</head>
<body>
    <header>
        <h1>Your Name</h1>
        <p>Email: your.email@example.com | Phone: 123-456-7890</p>
    </header>

    <section>
        <h2>Education</h2>
        <p><strong>University Name</strong>, Degree, Year</p>
        <p>Details about your degree or relevant coursework.</p>
    </section>

    <section>
        <h2>Work Experience</h2>
        <p><strong>Job Title</strong>, Company Name, Dates</p>
        <ul>
            <li>Detail about a specific responsibility or achievement.</li>
            <li>Another detail or project you worked on.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>

    <section>
        <h2>Skills</h2>
        <p>List of skills like programming languages, software tools, etc.</p>
    </section>

    <section>
        <h2>Projects</h2>
        <p><strong>Project Title</strong>, Technologies used</p>
        <p>Brief description of the project.</p>
    </section>

    <footer>
        <p>Connect with me on [LinkedIn/GitHub/Other social media] - [Link]</p>
    </footer>
</body>
</html>

    Instructions:

    1. Personalize the Content: Replace placeholders with your information (name, email, education, work experience, etc.).
    2. Expand Sections: Add or remove sections based on what you want to showcase.
    3. Styling: Use CSS to style the elements (colors, fonts, layout) to make your CV visually appealing.
    4. Adding Functionality: If needed, you can later incorporate JavaScript for interactive elements.

    This template is a starting point. As you grow more comfortable with web development, you can enhance it with more sophisticated features and styling.

    You
    how can I run that with vscode, i can't find the button run
    ChatGPT

    To view your HTML file created in Visual Studio Code (VS Code), you don't actually "run" it in the traditional sense like you would a Python script or a compiled program. Instead, you'll be opening it in a web browser. Here's how you can do it:

    1. Save the HTML File:

      • Ensure your document is saved with a .html extension, for example, resume.html.

    2. Open with a Web Browser:

      • Manually: Navigate to the folder where your HTML file is saved and double-click on the file. It should open in your default web browser.
      • Using VS Code:
        • Right-click on the HTML file in the Explorer panel within VS Code.
        • Select 'Open with Live Server' if you have the Live Server extension installed, or 'Reveal in File Explorer' to open the file location and then double-click on the file.

    3. Install 'Live Server' Extension (Optional but Recommended):

      • If you frequently work with HTML/CSS/JS, consider installing the 'Live Server' extension in VS Code.
      • To install:
        • Go to the Extensions view by clicking on the square icon on the left sidebar or pressing Ctrl+Shift+X.
        • Search for 'Live Server'.
        • Click 'Install' on the 'Live Server' extension.
      • To use:
        • Right-click on your HTML file and select 'Open with Live Server'.
        • This will launch your default browser and open your HTML file. The advantage of Live Server is that it auto-refreshes the browser whenever you make changes to your file.

    4. View and Refresh Manually:

      • If not using Live Server, you'll need to refresh your browser manually to see the changes each time you update and save your HTML file.

    Remember, HTML files are not "executed" like scripts; they are interpreted by web browsers. So, you're essentially just opening the file in a browser to see how it looks.

    Certainly, I can create an HTML template inspired by the structure of the CV/resume we discussed earlier. This template will be a basic HTML shell, providing a foundation upon which you can build and customize further.

    Here's a simple HTML template:

    html
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Your Name - Resume</title>
</head>
<body>
    <header>
        <h1>Your Name</h1>
        <p>Email: <a href="mailto:your.email@example.com">your.email@example.com</a> | Phone: 123-456-7890</p>
    </header>

    <section>
        <h2>Education</h2>
        <article>
            <h3>University Name</h3>
            <p>Degree, Year</p>
            <p>Details about your degree or relevant coursework.</p>
        </article>
    </section>

    <section>
        <h2>Work Experience</h2>
        <article>
            <h3>Job Title, Company Name</h3>
            <p>Dates of Employment</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Detail about a specific responsibility or achievement.</li>
                <li>Another detail or project you worked on.</li>
            </ul>
        </article>
    </section>

    <section>
        <h2>Skills</h2>
        <p>List of skills like programming languages, software tools, etc.</p>
    </section>

    <section>
        <h2>Projects</h2>
        <article>
            <h3>Project Title</h3>
            <p>Technologies used</p>
            <p>Brief description of the project.</p>
        </article>
    </section>

    <footer>
        <p>Connect with me on [LinkedIn/GitHub/Other social media] - <a href="your-social-media-link">Link</a></p>
    </footer>
</body>
</html>

    Instructions for Use:

    • Fill in Your Details: Replace placeholders (e.g., "Your Name", "University Name") with your personal information.
    • Add More Sections or Articles as Needed: Depending on your experience and what you want to showcase, you can add or remove sections or articles.
    • Hyperlinks: Replace the href attribute in <a> tags with your actual email address and links to your social media profiles.
    • Styling: This template is unstyled. Use CSS to style the elements and improve the visual appeal of your resume.
    • Additional Functionality: If you're comfortable with JavaScript, you can add interactive elements or dynamic content to your resume.

    This template is just a starting point. Feel free to customize it according to your needs and personal style.

        Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.
    </div>
    <div id="fullText" style="display: none;">
        Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.
    </div>

        <h3>Contacts</h3>
        <p>Address: Chaussée de Waterloo 1143, 1180 (Uccle) Bruxelles</p>
        <p>Email: jeanaboutboul@gmail.com</p>
        <p>Alternate Email: jeanaboutboul@icloud.com</p>
        <p>Phone: (+32) 470 66 60 43</p>
    </div>
</section>

<script>
    function showMore() {
        var shortText = document.getElementById("shortText");
        var fullText = document.getElementById("fullText");

        if (fullText.style.display === "none") {
            fullText.style.display = "block";
            shortText.style.display = "none";
        } else {
            fullText.style.display = "none";
            shortText.style.display = "block";
        }
    }
</script>

    In this setup:

    • The 'About Me' text is split into two parts: 'shortText' and 'fullText'.
    • Initially, only 'shortText' is visible, while 'fullText' is hidden (style="display: none").
    • The showMore() JavaScript function toggles the display of 'shortText' and 'fullText' when the "More" button is clicked.

    Remember to test this functionality in a browser to ensure it behaves as expected. The 'More' button will reveal the full text and hide the shorter text upon clicking, and vice versa.

    ChatGPT

    To separate the JavaScript into its own file, you'll need to create a new file named main.js and then reference it in your HTML. Here's how to do it:

    1. Create main.js file: This file will contain your JavaScript code.

    main.js:

    javascript
    function showMore() {
    var shortText = document.getElementById("shortText");
    var fullText = document.getElementById("fullText");

    if (fullText.style.display === "none") {
        fullText.style.display = "block";
        shortText.style.display = "none";
    } else {
        fullText.style.display = "none";
        shortText.style.display = "block";
    }
}
    1. Modify your HTML file: Update your HTML to reference the main.js file.

    In your HTML file:

    html
    <!-- ... (earlier parts of your HTML) ... -->

<section>
    <!-- ... (other content in the About Me section) ... -->
    <button onclick="showMore()">More</button>
    <!-- ... (rest of the section) ... -->
</section>

<!-- Reference to your JavaScript file -->
<script src="main.js"></script>

<!-- ... (rest of your HTML) ... -->

    Make sure main.js is in the same directory as your HTML file, or adjust the src path in the <script> tag accordingly if it's located elsewhere. This organization will keep your HTML and JavaScript neatly separated.

    You
    where do I putt the <script src="main.js"></script>
    ChatGPT

    The <script src="main.js"></script> tag should be placed right before the closing </body> tag in your HTML file. This is a common practice because it allows the HTML to be parsed and displayed to the user first, without waiting for the JavaScript file to be loaded and executed. This can improve the loading performance of your web page.

    Here is how it should look in your HTML file:

    html
    <!-- ... (rest of your HTML content) ... -->

<!-- Reference to your JavaScript file -->
<script src="main.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

    This ensures that all your HTML content is loaded before the JavaScript file is executed.

    In main.js:

    javascript
    function showMore() {
    var shortText = document.getElementById("shortText");
    var fullText = document.getElementById("fullText");
    var toggleButton = document.getElementById("toggleButton");

        fullText.style.display = "block";

    ChatGPT

    To achieve the effect of showing a descriptive bubble when hovering over a skill bubble, you'll need to use a combination of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Here's how you can set it up:

    HTML:

    html
    <section>
    <h3>Soft Skills and Strengths</h3>
    <div class="skills-bubble" onmouseover="showDescription('Creativity', event)" onmouseout="hideDescription()">Creativity</div>
    <!-- Repeat for other skills, changing the first argument to showDescription() as needed -->
</section>
<div id="descriptionBubble" style="display: none; position: absolute;"></div>

    JavaScript (in your main.js):

    javascript
    function showDescription(skill, event) {
    var descriptionBubble = document.getElementById('descriptionBubble');
    descriptionBubble.innerHTML = getDescription(skill);
    descriptionBubble.style.display = 'block';
    descriptionBubble.style.left = event.clientX + 'px';
    descriptionBubble.style.top = event.clientY + 'px';
}

function hideDescription() {
    var descriptionBubble = document.getElementById('descriptionBubble');
    descriptionBubble.style.display = 'none';
}

function getDescription(skill) {
    // Return a description based on the skill
    switch(skill) {
        case 'Creativity':
            return 'Ability to think outside the box.';
        // Add cases for other skills
        default:
            return '';
    }
}

    CSS:

    css
    #descriptionBubble {
    // Add styling for the description bubble
}

    In this setup:

    • When you hover over a skill bubble, showDescription() is called, showing a bubble with a description.
    • The getDescription() function returns a text based on the skill.
    • The description bubble's position is set based on the mouse's position.
    • When the mouse leaves a skill bubble, hideDescription() hides the description bubble.

    This will create an interactive effect where descriptions appear when you hover over each skill. You'll need to add specific descriptions for each skill in the getDescription() function.

    html
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Jean Aboutboul - Personal CV</title>
    <!-- Reference to your CSS file -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="main.css">
    <!-- ... other elements in the head ... -->
</head>
<body>
    <!-- ... your body content ... -->
</body>
</html>

    Ensure that the path in the href attribute correctly points to where your main.css file is located relative to your HTML file. For instance, if both files are in the same directory, just use href="main.css".

    The description show, but i want it to show just next to the skill buble not in a random place in the web page, can you fix that ?
    ChatGPT

    To make the description bubble appear next to each skill bubble, you need to adjust the positioning logic in your JavaScript function showDescription. The current approach using event.clientX and event.clientY positions the bubble relative to the viewport, not the skill bubble.

    Here's an updated approach using the skill bubble's bounding rectangle for positioning:

    javascript
    function showDescription(skill, event) {
    var descriptionBubble = document.getElementById('descriptionBubble');
    var skillBubbleRect = event.target.getBoundingClientRect();

    descriptionBubble.innerHTML = getDescription(skill);
    descriptionBubble.style.display = 'block';
    descriptionBubble.style.left = skillBubbleRect.left + 'px'; // Align with the left of the skill bubble
    descriptionBubble.style.top = (skillBubbleRect.top + skillBubbleRect.height + window.scrollY) + 'px'; // Position below the skill bubble
}

    This code will place the description bubble at the bottom left of each skill bubble. getBoundingClientRect provides the position of the skill bubble relative to the viewport, and window.scrollY is added to adjust for any scrolling on the page.

    1. Modify the showDescription Function: This function should display the description bubble as before.

    2. Create a New Function to Manage the Hover State: This function will check if the mouse is still over either the skill bubble or its description before deciding to hide the description.

    Updated JavaScript:

    javascript
    function showDescription(skill, event) {
    var descriptionBubble = document.getElementById('descriptionBubble');
    descriptionBubble.innerHTML = getDescription(skill);
    descriptionBubble.style.display = 'block';
    descriptionBubble.style.left = (event.clientX + 10) + 'px'; 
    descriptionBubble.style.top = (event.clientY + 10) + 'px';

function checkHoverState(event) {
    var descriptionBubble = document.getElementById('descriptionBubble');
    var isHovered = event.target === descriptionBubble || descriptionBubble.contains(event.relatedTarget) || event.target.classList.contains('skills-bubble');
    if (!isHovered) {
        descriptionBubble.style.display = 'none';
    }
}

    html
    <div class="skills-bubble" onmouseover="showDescription('Creativity', event)" onmouseout="checkHoverState(event)">Creativity</div>

    html
    <div id="descriptionBubble" onmouseout="checkHoverState(event)" style="display: none;"></div>

    In this setup, the checkHoverState function determines whether the mouse is still over the skill bubble or its description. The description bubble only disappears when the mouse leaves both elements. This approach should provide the user experience you described.

    5. Comments and Documentation: While good code should be self-explanatory, comments and documentation are important for complex logic or where clarification is needed.

    6. Consistency: Be consistent in your coding style. Whether it's naming conventions, code structure, or indentation, consistency makes your code more uniform and understandable.

    7. Testing: Ensure robustness through testing. Automated tests can help catch bugs and ensure that changes don't break existing functionality.

    For a detailed critique and more targeted suggestions, it would be beneficial to review the specific code files and their contents. You can apply these general principles to evaluate and improve your project.

    JavaScript for Text Animation: You'll need JavaScript to create the text animation effect. This is a simplified version, and you might need to use a library like Typed.js for a more complex effect.

    javascript
    const texts = ["Salut", "Ciao", "Hoi", "Hi! I'm Jean"];
let count = 0;
let index = 0;
let currentText = '';
let letter = '';

(function type() {
    if (count === texts.length) {
        count = 0;
    }
    currentText = texts[count];
    letter = currentText.slice(0, ++index);

    document.querySelector('.animation-text').textContent = letter;
    if (letter.length === currentText.length) {
        count++;
        index = 0;
    }
    setTimeout(type, 300);
}());

    Smooth Scrolling to Sections: This typically requires JavaScript to detect scroll events and then scroll to the next section. Libraries like fullPage.js can handle such behavior.

    Please Note:

    • The text animation and scrolling behavior might need further refinement or the use of external libraries for smoother effects.
    • This is a foundational structure. You should test and adjust it to fit your exact design and functionality needs.
    • For the taskbar and contact circle, additional styling and functionality (like linking to sections) are needed.

    ChatGPT

    I'll provide the modified CSS code for enlarging the text of the animation, moving it more to the right, and adding a cursor-like effect, as seen in text editors.

    CSS (Updated for Animation Text and Cursor):

    css
    .animation-text {
    /* Existing styles */
    font-family: 'Chivo', sans-serif; /* Or choose between 'Oswald' and 'Space Mono' */
    color: #D32F2F; /* Match the color to h1, h2, h3 */
    font-size: 2em; /* Make the text larger */
    margin-left: 30%; /* Position the text more to the right */
}

/* Styles for the text cursor */
.animation-text::after {
    content: '|';
    display: inline-block;
    animation: blink 1s step-start 0s infinite;
}

/* Keyframes for blinking cursor effect */
@keyframes blink {
    50% {
        opacity: 0;
    }
}

    This CSS will make the animated text larger and position it further to the right. The ::after pseudo-element adds a cursor-like '|' character after the animated text, and the @keyframes rule creates a blinking effect.

    To see these changes in action, replace the existing CSS for .animation-text in your main.css file with the provided CSS code. This should give you the desired look and feel for the text animation on your first page. ​​
